results.title: Brown bears go fishing
results.brief_description: This film aims to stimulate interest in reading and to increase the vocabulary of primary pupils by using over prints and repetition in the narration. While reading and looking at storybooks, a group of children learn about the habits of polar bears and American black bears. Shows Alaskan brown bears swimming in a stream, catching and eating salmon, fighting over fish and teaching cubs how to swim.

results.title: Brothers Manakia - Pioneers of Greek and Balkan Cinema
results.brief_description: This film traces the history of Yannis and Miltos Manakia, beginning at their place of birth, the Macedonian village of Abdela, where the first Greek film “The Weavers” was made by the Manakia brothers in 1905, laying the foundations of the Greek and Balkan Cinema.

results.title: Brothers keeper [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Hand to Mouth Productions, American Playhouse Theatrical Films, Joe Berlinger and Bruce Sinofsky
results.brief_description: This award-winning documentary focuses on a controversial murder trial that took place in the Upstate New York farming community of Munnsville in 1990. 59 year old Delbert Ward, one of four reclusive, eccentric brothers who shared the same dilapidated two-room shack on their dairy farm for over 60 years, was accused of murder when his ailing older brother was found dead in the bed they shared. After being interrogated by the state police, the simple-minded and barely literate Delbert signed a confession stating that he smothered his brother as an act of mercy. Believing him incapable of murder, and not possessing the mental capacity to understand police bureaucracy, the local community rallied around Delbert and his brothers, raising bail in a matter of hours. The film covers the period between Delbert’s arrest and his trial, focusing on the daily lives of the ‘Ward boys’ as national media scrutiny intensifies around them. As the state police gather ‘evidence’ that incest was a motive for the killing, the local community’s support for the outcast Ward brothers strengthens. Interviews with state police and prosecuters, local residents and Delbert’s lawyer build the case for and against the accused. An intriguing, compelling and unashamedly subjective real-life murder mystery that goes beyond simply telling a good story to reveal the part the media plays in the formation of personal and community identity.

results.title: Brothers in trouble
results.creator_credit: Robert Buckler, BBC Film Unit, Renegade Films and Udayan Prasad
results.brief_description: This film presents an insightful look into the immigrant experience in Britain. Amir arrives illegally to England in the 1960’s. His arrival is less than grand, arriving in a vegetable crate, but he is willing to endure this indignity to find a better life than the one he had in India. His expectations are of wealth, opportunity and prosperity but instead he finds himself dissilusioned, sharing a house with seventeen other illegal immigrants in Northern England. They find themselves working in factories, no better off than the existence they left. Their lifestyle is punctuated by the comings and goings of agents, police informers, occasional enjoyable trips to the cinema to see Indian films and a weekly visit by a prostitute. Into their world arrives Mary, an illegal immigrant from Ireland that house leader Hussein Shah meets in a cafe. At first Mary brings hope and happiness to the household but when she announces that she is pregnant, traditional patriarch Hussein arranges a marriage of convenience between Mary and his nephew. Tension arises when the males of the household object to Mary’s free spirited ways. Starring Om Puri, Pavan Malhotra and Angeline Ball.

results.title: Brotherhood of man
results.creator_credit: Stephen Bosustow, United Productions of America and Robert Cannon
results.brief_description: This film was made as a contribution to “Brotherhood Week” held in the USA in 1946, in which President Truman called on Americans to see that fair practices were the rule in both private and industrial life. The film is based on the pamphlet “Races of Mankind”, written by Dr.Ruth Benedict and Gene Weltfish, anthropologists of Columbia University USA, and published in 1943. “Brotherhood of man” explodes a number of commonly held fallacies which lead to racial discrimination and group persecution. It gives a clear scientific exposition of a number of basic biological and historical facts, which demonstrate the fundamental identity of humanity, stressing the need for tolerance and co-operation between all groups and races since human beings are always dependent on other human beings. It uses humor rather than drama to make its points. The soundtrack of this film was translated and re-recorded for use by the USA Occupation forces in Europe.

results.title: Brother sun sister moon
results.creator_credit: Luciano Perugia, Euro International and Franco Zeffirelli
results.brief_description: This delicate, handsome, quasi-fictional biography of one of the great saints of the Catholic Church, Francis of Assisi, focuses on the early years of his life. Saint Francis, who sought communion with the natural world by renouncing his family;s riches to seek his own destiny unencumbered by material possessions. Francis was, in a sense, history’s first “drop-out” ; he left a life of comfort to seek a spiritual union with the world. Starring Graham Faulkner as Francis and Judi Bowker as the young girl who eventually sheds her materialistic existence for religious poverty, this visually stunning film was nominate for a Best Art Direction Academy Award in 1973.

results.title: Brother bear
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney Pictures, Aaron Blaise and Bob Walker
results.brief_description: Disney animated feature film about North American Indian boy Kenai (voice by Joaquin Phoenix) who is mysteriously transformed into a bear. Kenai then has to view the world through the eyes of the bear, providing him (and the viewer) with important lessons in life. He is befriend by a bear cub, Koda, who accompanies him through his journey, encountering a range of other wildlife and humans along the way. Features songs by Phil Collins.

results.title: Brother
results.brief_description: The childhood memory of a brother, his cigarette butts, asthma and head lice. An exploration of the simple truths and ironies that make up a life. An iconic Australian film.
results.description: The childhood memory of a brother, his cigarette butts, asthma and head lice. An exploration of the simple truths and ironies that make up a life. An iconic Australian film.

results.title: Brother
results.creator_credit: Adam Elliot and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Through the narration, we recall events in the lives of two young brothers growing up in the suburbs. We learn about “getting the blame” for things you didn’t do, and that if the devil doesn’t get you then karma will. Above all we see how two brothers deal with an alcoholic father, disease and asthma. Narrated by William McInnes. This clay animation film forms part of the autobiographical trilogy that includes “Uncle”, “Brother” and “Cousin”.

results.title: Brother
results.creator_credit: Office Kitano, Recorded Picture Company, Film Four International, Bac Films (France), Jeremy Thomas, Masayuki Mori and Takeshi Kitano
results.brief_description: Takeshi “Beat” Kitano went to the United States of America to film this cross-cultural gangster Yakuza film. Takeshi himself plays an exiled yakuza hitman who lands in Los Angeles with a bag of stolen money and resentful of his banishment from the home country. He finds his half-brother (Omar Epps) and together they attempt to take over the drug trade in Los Angeles. A return to highly kinetic crime fiction, “Brother” finds Takeshi Kitano in a much more playful mood after the personal reflections of “Hani-Bi”. Whipping furiously across the genre tropes of the gangster film and the Yakuza film, “Brother” emerges as a highly satisfying ride with deftly executed sequences of violence and warrior mayhem. The cultural differences between the two brothers - one being Japanese and the other being African-American - allows for some genuinely funny reflections on cultural and ethnic misunderstandings, but nothing allows the action to stop for a moment. In Japanese and English with English subtitles.
